title: 103_hr4695
content: PROCEDURES FOR SEEKING COMPENSATION. Compensation procedures for wrongfully arrested individuals are established under Chapter 4 of title 39, United States Code. Individuals arrested by the Postal Inspection Service after December 31, 1983, in investigations involving paid confidential informants may seek compensation. Regulations for seeking compensation must be established within 90 days of the enactment of this section. Compensation procedures for wrongfully arrested individuals involving paid confidential informants must be sought within 2 years after exhausting all available administrative and judicial procedures. The compensation process for wrongfully arrested individuals involving paid confidential informants must be initiated within 2 years after exhausting all administrative and judicial procedures. Petitions for compensation will be reviewed by a panel of 3 administrative law judges who are qualified and detailed to the Postal Service on a reimbursable basis. Proceedings will follow the provisions of sections 556 and 557 of title 5. The panel of 3 administrative law judges may award compensation up to $500,000 to a wrongfully arrested petitioner, their spouse, or child for harm suffered. Compensation will be paid from the Postal Service Fund, based on the extent of harm and failure of the Postal Inspection Service. The Postal Inspection Service failed to take reasonable precautions to prevent wrongful arrests, and the panel of administrative law judges may award compensation up to $500,000 to the wrongfully arrested petitioner. The determination under this section is not subject to review. The term 'administrative law judge' refers to a judge appointed under section 3105 of title 5. A confidential informant is considered 'paid' if they receive any benefit for their services. The analysis for chapter 4 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to include these definitions. "Compensation for wrongfully arrested individuals under section 414."
